column6: This plant is suspected of being poisonous to mammals[76]. It also looks very similar to some very poisonous species so great care must be taken when identifying it[12].
column7: A very common plant of roadsides, hedges etc[5].
column8: Most of Europe, including Britain, south and east to N. Africa and Siberia.
column13: Fully Hardy,Well drained soil,Moist Soil,Full shade,Semi-shade,Full sun
column15: A herbaceous biennial or short-lived perennial plant in the family Apiaceae and related to parsley, carrot, hemlock and hogweed. that can be confused with giant cow parsley (Heracleum mantegazzianum) or French cow parsley (Orlaya grandiflora). Some medicinal, edible and other uses although it does have an unpleasant flavour. Common names include cow parsley, wild chervil, wild beaked parsley, keck,or Queen Anne's lace.
column16: Anthriscus sylvestris is a BIENNIAL growing to 1.2 m (4ft) by 0.6 m (2ft in).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 7 and is not frost tender.  It is in flower from April to June, and the seeds ripen from June to July. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Bees. The plant is self-fertile.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It can grow in full shade (deep woodland) semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers dry or  moist soil.
column18: Woodland Garden Dappled Shade; Shady Edge; Hedgerow;
column19: Leaves: ,Root: includes bulbs, corms, tubers, rhizomes etc.
column21: The leaves are eaten raw, cooked as a potherb or used as a flavouring[5, 12, 53, 183]. They taste somewhat less than wonderful[K]. Root - cooked[183].
column22: Tonic: Improves general health. Slower acting than a stimulant, it brings steady improvement.
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.TonicThe root is soaked for several days in rice washings and then cooked with other foods as a tonic for general weakness[218].
column25: A beautiful green dye is obtained from the leaves and stem but it is not very permanent[115].
column27: Succeeds in most soils. Shade tolerant[31]. The root has been recommended for improvement by selection and breeding as an edible crop[183]. This plant looks quite similar to some poisonous species, make sure that you identify it correctly.
column28: Seed - sow as soon as ripe (June/July) in situ. The seed can also be sown April/May in situ. It usually germinates in 1 - 3 months at 20°c.
